stem: The client with a T6 spinal cord injury is exhibiting signs and symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia. Based on the information provided in the EHR, identify all findings that support this diagnosis. Click on those findings.

itemContext.sbar:
S: John Smith is a 45-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, admitted 3 weeks ago for rehabilitation. He is currently experiencing symptoms suggestive of autonomic dysreflexia.

B: The patient sustained the spinal cord injury in a motor vehicle accident. His rehabilitation has been progressing well until today. He has no known history of autonomic dysreflexia episodes, but this is not uncommon post-spinal cord injury.

A: At 0700, the patient reported a severe headache and feeling flushed. His blood pressure is significantly elevated at 210/110 mmHg, and his heart rate is notably low at 52 bpm. He is also exhibiting diaphoresis above the level of his injury and reports feeling anxious, although he denies any pain.

O: I am concerned about possible autonomic dysreflexia. I will assess the patient for potential causes, such as bladder distention or bowel impaction. I will elevate the head of the bed and monitor his vital signs closely. I will notify the physician immediately with any changes or if the symptoms persist beyond 15 minutes or worsen. I have also checked for any skin irritation or pressure points.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: The client's elevated blood pressure (210/110 mmHg), bradycardia (52 bpm), headache, flushing, and diaphoresis above the level of injury are all classic signs and symptoms of autonomic dysreflexia. These findings indicate an exaggerated sympathetic response to a noxious stimulus below the level of the spinal cord injury.
rationale.incorrect: Normal lab values (WBC, Hemoglobin, Sodium), and the medications listed on the MAR (Docusate Sodium and PRN Oxycodone) are not directly indicative of autonomic dysreflexia. While constipation (treated by docusate) can be a trigger, the medication itself doesn't confirm the diagnosis. The normal lab values rule out infection or significant electrolyte imbalances that could indirectly contribute to the symptoms.
clinicalPearls: Always assess for potential triggers of autonomic dysreflexia, such as bladder distention, bowel impaction, or skin irritation.
Elevate the head of the bed immediately to lower blood pressure.
Administer antihypertensive medications as prescribed if conservative measures are ineffective.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus on individual vital signs without considering the constellation of symptoms that define autonomic dysreflexia. Some may get distracted by the medications listed, assuming they are causing the issue, rather than the underlying spinal cord injury.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the importance of synthesizing information from all available sources and recognizing patterns that are consistent with specific diagnoses. Encourage students to prioritize the most relevant findings and consider the client's medical history.

mnemonic.title: HEAD
mnemonic.expansion: H- Headache, Elevated BP; E- Evaluate cause; A- Antihypertensives; D- Dilation (nasal congestion), Diaphoresis (above injury)
